para.paratext:
The weight to assign evidence is a matter for the jury. The party having the burden of persuasion must carry that burden by the degree of proof required in his case. The degree of proof is usually a preponderance of the evidence in civil actions and beyond a reasonable doubt in criminal prosecutions. The weight of evidence may become a legal issue through a question of whether the evidence supports the verdict or as an objection to the judge's charge to the jury.[
1]

The Georgia General Assembly has established a greater burden of proof in some causes of actions. For example, O.C.G.A. § 24-12-21 (disclosure of HIV confidential information), O.C.G.A. § 19-7-1 (custody disputes between a biological parent and third parties), O.C.G.A. § 29-5-6 (guardianship of alleged incapacitated adult), and O.C.G.A. § 51-12-5.1 (recovery of punitive damages in tort actions). [2]

Georgia courts have also required an elevated standard of proof in specific types of cases, usually involving more than a monetary loss. For example, termination of parental rights, third-party custody disputes, the involuntary commitment or sterilization of a person,[3] and proving an oral contract to convey land or to devise land in a will.[
4]

Anderson v. Reese, 85 Ga. App. 437, 69 S.E.2d 656 (1952). This was a trover action for cattle in which the jury told the judge that they did not believe that either the plaintiff or the defendant owned the cattle. The judge charged that, if they did not believe that the plaintiff owned the cattle, they should find for the defendant.

Young v. Looper, 211 Ga. 470, 86 S.E.2d 293 (1955) , was a trespass action for cutting timber where both plaintiff and defendant claimed to own the land. Judge charged the jury that if they found that the land was not the property of the plaintiff, but was the property of the defendant, they should find for the defendant. This charge was erroneous because the plaintiff had the burden of proving ownership and if he failed to carry this burden, he could not prevail. There was no burden on the defendant to prove ownership.

See Coxwell v. Coxwell, 296 Ga. 311, 765, 765 S.E.2d 320 (2014) (Supreme Court held that the appropriate standard to determine the terms of an antenuptial agreement that was lost was a preponderance of the evidence).

See also O.C.G.A. § 15-11-65, setting the standard of proof in a juvenile delinquent/unruly case as beyond a reasonable doubt and O.C.G.A. § 15-11-94, setting the standard of proof in a juvenile deprivation case as clear and convincing evidence.

In In Interest of C.D.L., 184 Ga. App. 412, 361 S.E.2d 527 (1987), the court relied on O.C.G.A. § 15-11-33(c) to hold that the standard of proof is beyond a reasonable doubt where the offense charged against a juvenile would be a crime if committed by an adult (delinquent offenses).

See e.g., Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 102 S. Ct. 1388, 71 L. Ed. 2d 599 (1982) (requiring “clear and convincing” standard of proof in a proceeding to terminate parental rights); Motes v. Hall County Dept. of Family and Children Services, 251 Ga. 373, 306 S.E.2d 260 (1983) (requiring “clear and convincing” standard of proof in involuntary sterilization); Clark v. Wade, 273 Ga. 587, 544 S.E.2d 99 (2001) (requiring “clear and convincing” standard of proof in a third party custody dispute).
But see Williams General Corp. v. Stone, 279 Ga. 428, 614 S.E.2d 758 (2005) (refusing to require to a heightened evidentiary standard to civil RICO claims under the Georgia statute).

Barnes v. Bell, 206 Ga. 660, 58 S.E.2d 400 (1950); Harper v. Hudson, 210 Ga. 751, 82 S.E.2d 854 (1954); Hudson v. Hampton, 220 Ga. 165, 137 S.E.2d 644 (1964); Liberty Nat. Bank & Trust Co. v. Diamond, 229 Ga. 677, 194 S.E.2d 91 (1972); Walls v. Savage, 243 Ga. 198, 253 S.E.2d 183 (1979) .
